bullet_points.description: Jain religious tradition believes that the universe is eternal and exists as a continuum, emphatically negating the concept of a ‘CREATOR GOD’.
The eternal repetitive cycle of time is called _‘Kalachakra’_ – wheel of time.

_Kalachakra_ is divided into two half cycles: _Avasarpini_, a period of increasing sorrow and immorality; and _Utsarpini_, a period of progressive prosperity and abundant happiness. Each period is divided into six _aras_ (spokes of time). (See details on display)

The first three _ara-s_ of the Kalachakra represent the Golden Age of abundance, and peaceful coexistence among all living beings. The concept of _Kalpavriksha_ – The Tree of Prosperity - in all its splendour, symbolized complete contentment in the golden age. (See details on display)

As societies evolved, communities (_kula_) settled. The chief of the community –_Kulakara_ – introduced processes of discipline, law and order; approved and accepted by society.(See details on display)
The tradition of _Kulakaras_ ended when Rishabhadeva became the first Tirthankara in the third-_ara_.
Today, we are in the fifth _ara_ of the _current cycle_ - _Avasarpini_.

When settled communities emerged, limited resources and increasing wants led to disputes. Kulakar - chief of the community, established discipline; and law and order for a structured society.Kulakars introduced systems of governance and methods of restraint like _Hakkara_ – caution, _Makkara_ –prohibit and _Dhikkara_ – reprimand.
Over time, there were fourteen _Kulakaras_ till the tradition ended when Rishabhadev became the first Tirthankar in the third _ara_.
The 14th and last Kulakar of the present Avasarpini period was Nabhi.  Rishabhadev was Nabhi and his wife Marudevi’s son.

Shantinatha, the 16th Tirthankara of this ara was the first _chakravartin_ (emperor) to become a Tirthankara. Known for his compassion and power to heal, he brought peace to a strife-ridden kingdom that was engulfed in chaos.

Shantinath’s birthplace Hastinapur, struck by plague before his birth, is believed to have recovered from the calamity when he was conceived. So, his parents named him Shantinatha and chanting his name ‘Shanti’, has the power to usher in peace.
Malli, the 19th Tirthankara was a woman according to Shvetambara tradition.
She was a princess renowned for her extraordinary beauty and charisma. Not being disillusioned with worldly pleasures she always harboured the feeling of renunciation;
she not only attained kevala jnana herself, she also initiated six princes infatuated with her and were desirous of marrying her into renunciation and enlightenment.
Born in the Harivamsha clan, Munisuvrata, was the king of Rajgir (Bihar).

Munisuvrata, belonged to the same era as Rama, the highly revered central character in the epic Valmiki _Ramayana_. In the Jain tradition, Rama is referred to as ‘Padma’ and venerated as one of the 63 distinguished personalities.
On Kankali Tila, a mound located in Mathura, there is archaeological evidence of a Jain stupa dating back to the 2nd Century BCE that.

The city of Mathura, Uttar Pradesh was an important centre for the three ancient Indian religious traditions  - Jainism, Buddhism and Hinduism. Jainism flourished here for a continuous period of 14 centuries from 2nd century BCE to 12th century CE.

Mathura is usually associated with Krishna and the Mahabharata. However, what is less commonly known is the importance and antiquity of Mathura in the Jain tradition. Sculptures, architectural fragments and inscriptions found during archaeological excavations establish the city’s antiquity.
The Mathura inscriptions show that Jainism was practiced by a vibrant society and a strong bond was established between ascetics and householders - a vital aspect of Jainism even today.
Kharavela was a king of Chedi dynasty. He ruled Kalinga in present day Odisha, India in approximately first century BCE.

The main source of information about king Kharavela is the 17 line Hathigumpha Inscription. The Prakrit inscription contains detailed account of Kharavela’s reign upto the thirteenth year in perfect chronological order.
He was a follower of Jainism along with members of his family. There are inscriptions recording erection of a Jina temple and the building of some caves by Kharavela and his queens.
The Hathigumpha Inscription describes him as a worshipper of all religious orders. The inscription starts with salutation to ‘siddhas’ and ‘arhats’.
It further mentions that King Kharavela invaded Magadha (Bihar) and retrieved the Jina image (referred to in the inscription as Kalinga Jina).
The image was taken away by a king of the Nanda dynasty in the 4th cent BCE (approx. 2500 years before today).
According to some scholars, a council was also convened by Kharavela in 1st cent BCE.
Pale Cave (approx 9.3 km from this site) and Lohagad Cave (26 km by road from this site, approx 10 km as the crow flies) are the earliest known Jain caves in Western India. ​
The inscriptions in both these caves state that both the caves had a common supporter named Iddarakhita (Indrarakshita).
Arya Rakshita had the knowledge of more than nine ‘Purva’s -  ancient texts which are now extinct.
His works include the Anuyogadvara-sutra (अनुयोगद्वारसूत्र), a treatise on theory of knowledge; besides a wide range of teachings on other religious treatises.

Gunadharasvami composed Kashaya-pahuda (कषायपाहुड) on the basis of Drishtivada - ancient texts which are now extinct. Till this time all the knowledge was in oral form. This is one of the earliest texts in Jain tradition that was written down.
Alarmed at the gradual dwindling away of the Tirthankaras’ teachings,  Dharasena summoned ascetics Pushpadanta and Bhutabali, to his retreat on Mount Girnar in Gujarat.​​

It is believed that during Dharasena’s time, knowledge of only a part of Mahavira’s message viz., the _Drishtivada_ - ancient texts which are now extinct -  had been preserved. He communicated whatever he recalled of the vast extent of the original teachings.
These were arranged as the _Shatkhandagama_ (Scripture in Six Parts) - a text in _Shauraseni_ Prakrit (शौरसेनीप्राकृत).

The Yapaniya sect was an important part of Jain tradition, along with the Digambaras and the Shvetambaras. Literary evidence suggests that the Yapaniya sect flourished around the 1st century CE, approx.. 2100 years ago. The Yapaniyas held a doctrinal position between the Shvetambaras and the Digambaras on certain key beliefs. For instance, they agreed with the Shvetambaras that women could attain salvation, which the Digambaras rejected. However, Yapaniya ascetics followed the Digambara code of conduct.

The first mention of the Yapaniya sect appears in an inscription by Kadamba King Mrigesavarman (475-490 CE), while the last known inscription referencing the sect dates back to Saka 1316 (1394 CE)​, discovered in southwest Karnataka.
Acharya Kundkund, an acharya in the Digambar tradition, systematized essential philosophical doctrines.
His works Samaysar, Niyamsar, Pravachansar and Panchastikay are among his major contributions in Jain literature.
Samaysar, a unique treatise on Jain spiritualism, discusses the real nature of the soul, karm and moksha.
Acharya Umasvati/Umasvami, also known as Vachaka (narrator), is revered by both Digambara and Shvetambara traditions.
He systemized Jain principles presenting them in his seminal work ‘Tattvartha Sutra’also known as ‘Moksha Shastra’.
Ancient  Jain texts were written in various Prakrit languages. ‘Tattvartha Sutra’ was the first comprehensive text Written in Sanskrit on Jain philosophy.

list.title: Pallava rulers (3rd cent to 8th cent CE, Tamilnadu )

bullet_points.description: Pallava rulers supported the spread of Jainism. The Jain temple at  Jinakanchi (Tamil Nadu), known as Trailokyanath temple received a grant from Pallava rulers Simhavarman and his son Simhavishnu.
The temple also received grants from later kings - of Chola (c. 9th to 13th cent CE) and Vijaynagar rule (14th to 17th cent CE) dynasties.
According to Shvetambar tradition, in the 4th century CE, nine centuries after Mahavira nirvana, a great famine gripped the country. Severe  starvation resulted in the death of many Jain ascetics .
When the famine receded, a Council presided over by Arya Skandila, was convened at Mathura to collect whatever knowledge of the Tirthanakaras’  teachings were available.
The process of writing the teachings began with this Council, known as Mathuri Vachana.
According to Shvetambar tradition, a Council was also held at Valabhi in 4th cent CE, under Nagarjuna Suri, a contemporary of Arya Skandila.
Another Council was held at Valabhu in the 5th Century CE.

list.title: Ganga Dynasty (4th – 11th cent CE, South Karnataka)

bullet_points.description: Jainism flourished for about seven centuries under the Gang kings - the longest ruling dynasty in India.

Simhanandi, a Jain Acharya, helped Gang kings come to power. Since then, Jain Acharyas have played an influential role as king makers and royal preceptors. Many Gang kings were devout Jains and consecrated several Jin images, built temples, Jain monuments and commissioned caves to be carved for Jain ascetics. This was a powerful period for Jainism in the South India under the rule of Jain kings.
The monumental monolithic statue of Bahubali at Shravanabelgola (983 CE) was commissioned by Chavundaraya, a minister of Ganga kings.

The Kadamba dynasty, which ruled over Northern Karnataka, supported Jainism in South India. Some royal family members were Jains. Inscriptional evidence indicates presence of a considerable Jain population in the region.
Grants were offered to Jain establishments and sects, such as Nirgranthas (Digambars), Shvetapats (Shvetambars), Yapaniys, and Kurchaks. Yapaniy and Kurchak sects no longer exist.

Important inscriptions indicate that religious traditions were fluid and not rigidly compartmentalized. Individual members within a family, among royalty as well as common people, parallelly followed both Jainism and Sanatan Dharma. This highlighted the existence of a collaborative and mutually supportive society.
**Acharya Pujyapada** was a poet, philosopher, grammarian and expert on indigenous medicine.

He composed many important texts, which helped in the promotion of Jainism in the south. One of his most renowned text is _Sarvarthasiddhi_ (सर्वार्थसिद्धि), a commentary on the _Tattvartha-sutra_(तत्त्वार्थसूत्र).

Acharya Samantabhadra was a poet, logician, eulogist and an accomplished linguist. Credited with spreading Jain religious tradition in southern India, Samantabhadra worked extensively and further developed the Jain theory of Syadvada.
Acharya Siddhasena Divakara is revered by both Shvetambar and Digambar traditions. ​

Initiated into asceticism by Acharya Vriddhavadi (वृद्धवादी), he founded the Jain system of logic. His works cover a range of literature - hymns and praise, and works on logic and religion. some of his important texts are - Nyayavatara (न्यायावतार) (Descent of Logic), Dvatrinshika (द्वात्रिन्शिका), Sanmatisutra (सन्मति-सूत्र) (Logic of Right Wisdom), Kalyana-mandira-stotra (कल्याण-मंदिर-स्तोत्र).
Many hymns composed by him, each of 32 verses, played a crucial part in the development of the later hymn literature.
Acharya Bhadrabahu-II wrote commentaries (niryuktis) on ten works of Shvetambara scriptures (agamas).
He was brother of famous indian astronomer, astrologer and mathematician Varahamihira.
Acharya Yativrishabh composed the  _Tiloya-pannatti_ (तिलोय-पण्णति), a text on Jain cosmography. It also comprises the biography of the 24 Tirthankaras and the tradition of Jain teachers.​

list.title: Acharya Manatunga 7th cen. CE Shvetambar and Digambar traditions

bullet_points.description: Acharya Manatunga, revered by Shvetambar and Digambar traditions, wrote the _Bhaktamara Strota_, in Sanskrit in the7th Cent CE. The _stotra_ with 48 chandas (verses) is regularly recited by the Jain devotees even today.

Written while imprisoned by a king, it is believed that the prison locks miraculously opened when Manatunga recited the verses. Each verse reveals Manatunga’s infinite devotion and belief in the Jina.

list.title: Eastern Chalukyas (Chalukyas of Vengi) 7th to 12th cent CE

bullet_points.description: Several inscriptions of the Eastern Chalukya kings record donations for construction of Jain temples; and gift of lands and money for their maintenance.
Acharya Akalanka is renowned for his significant contribution in shaping  Jain logic.
Among his major contributions to Jain literature are works on cognition, the theory-of omniscience and the theory of _Anekantavada_ (Relative Pluralism).​

He composed the outstanding _Raja-vartika_ (राज-वार्तिक) (Royal Commentary) on the _Tattvartha-sutra_ (तत्त्वार्थ-सूत्र), and the _Aptamimaṁsa-ashtasahasri_ (आप्तमीमांसा-अष्टसहस्त्री) (Eight Thousand Verses on Logic), _Laghiyastraya_  (लघीयस्त्रय) (on Epistemology).
**Acharya Haribhadra Suri** wrote in Sanskrit and Prakrit languages on subjects like yoga, logic, code of conduct, astrology, astronomy, cosmography and cosmology as well as commentaries.
With his compendium of _Shad-Darshana-Samuchchaya_ (षड्दर्शन-समुच्चय) (Six Philosophies), he created a novel style of presenting logic, in an era noted for the quality of its philosophical debates.
_Dharmabindu_ (धर्मबिंदु) (The Essence of Religion) is a major contribution outlining the religious life of the laity.​
Also a poet, **Haribhadra Suri** wrote satires - _Dhurtakhyana_ _(धूर्ताख्यान,_ romantic tales - _Samaraïchchakaha_ _(समराइच्चकहा)_ and stories - _Kathakosha_ _(कथाकोष)_ in Prakrit.
**He was a teacher of his royal patron prince Ama (आम),who became King of Kannauj **(Uttar Pradesh).

He was a great orator and author, winning public esteem for composing eulogies of the twenty-four tirthankaras, _Caturvimshati-jinastuti_ and Sarasvati - the goddess of learning, _Sarasvati-stotra_ which remain popular even today.
According to a 14th cent CE text Vividh-tirth-kalp, the Jain stupa at Mathura was restored by Bappabhatti Suri.

Many of the Rashtrakuta kings were Jains and so were their ministers and feudatories. This was probably the most flourishing period of Jainism in South India. Jainism thrived during the Rashtrakut period, especially under Jain king Amoghavarsha.  Manyakhet (Gulbarga District in Karnataka), the Rashtrakut capital, became a renowned centre for Jain education and literature.

The literary activity of the Jain scholars of this period was remarkable. Many noteworthy literary works were created during this time by scholars and poets like  Samantabhadra, Akalanka, Vidyananda, Manikyanandin, Prabhachandra, Jinasena, Gunachandra, Pampa.​ Important Digambara texts and commentaries were written in this period.
Jain rock - cut caves at Ellora are one of the most splendid examples of Jain architecture of Rashtrakut period.
Acharya Virasena was one of the outstanding minds in the court of Amoghavarsha-I of the Rastrakuta dynasty.

Noted for his commentary _Dhavala_(धवला) on _Shatkhandagama_ (षट्खंडागम). He had also begun composing the commentary _Jayadhavala_(जयधवला) on _Kashayaprabhrita_ (कषायप्रभृत), which was later completed by Jinasena.
Jinasen was the preceptor of Rashtrakut king, Amoghavarsh.

While he completed the commentary begun by his teacher, Virasen, titled _Jayadhaval (जयधवला)_ on _Kashayaprabhrit (कषायप्रभृत)_, Jinasen’s  famous poetic work was Adipuran which is the biography of the first Tirthankar Rishabhadev and the first Chakravarti Bharat.
Gunabhadra was the preceptor of Rashtrakut king Krishna II.

He completed the _Adipuran_ and composed _Uttarapuran_ which comprises the biographies of later 23 Tirthankars from Ajitanath to Mahavir 11 Chakravartis (चक्रवर्ति), 9 Narayans (नारायण), 9 Pratinarayans (प्रतिनारायण), 9 Baladev. Both these texts together form the epic _Mahapuran_ (महापुराण).
**Acharya Shilank**  wrote commentaries on 11 angas, of which only two are available today -  commentaries on _Acharanga_(आचारांग) and _Sutrakritanga_(सूत्रकृतांग).
His independent work is _Chaupanna Mahapuris-chariy (चौपन्नमहापुरिस-चरिय)_ - biographies of 54 illustrious personalities - 24 Tirthankaras, 12 Chakravarti, 9 Vasudev and 9 Baladev.
**Acharya Vidyananda Suri** 9th cen. CE was a prominent Acharya in the rule of **Ganga King Shivamara-II. **
Author of nine texts, he was proficient in philosophy, grammar and poetry alike.
Some of his important works are _Tattvartha-shlokavartika, Ashtasahasri, Yuktyanu-shasanalankara, _and Aptapariksha.

Mahaviracharya  was a South Indian Jain scholar of Mathematics. His _Ganita - sara - samgraha _(Compendium of the Essence of Mathematics’), written in Sanskrit, is a significant work in the history of Indian Mathematics.
This is the first Jain text entirely devoted to mathematics, distinguishing astrology from mathematics.

In the nine chapters, this work states 1,129 versified rules and examples in arithmetic and geometry, including terminology and mathematical procedures. It also specifies rules for computation of ‘zero’ and negative quantities.
Acharya Ratnaprabha Suri was a shvetambara acharya who is credited with establishing Oswal Community on the bank of Osia river and spreading Jainism in Rajasthan.
Acharya Amritachandra Suri was better known as a commentator of many texts composed by Acharya Kundakunda’s, including Samayasara, Pravachanasara, Niyamasara.
His other works include, Purushartha-siddhyupay, Tattvarthasaraand  Paramarth Tarangini (परमार्थतरंगिणी).
Acharya Somadev Suri composed _Nitivakyamritam_ -  an important text on political science, the first by any Jain author.
Some of his other texts are _Yashastilakachampu_ -  a prosaic novel remarkable for its deep knowledge of Sanskrit grammar, meter and idiom, comparable to the best of Sanskrit poetry;
_Adhyatmatarangini_ - a text dealing with spiritual aspects of Jainism
**Acharya Manikyanandi** 10th -11th cen. CE belonged to Nandi sangha. He was eminent scholar of _Nyayashastra_. His main work was _Pariksha-mukha-sutram_.

Acharya Prabhachandra, disciple of Acharya Manikyanandi,  wrote a commentary titiled, _Prameya-kamala-martanda_ on Manikyanandi’s _Pariksha-mukha-sutra, Nyaya-kumuda-chandra, Laghiyastraya-vyakhya, _among others.
Jainism received impetus during the regime of Chalukyas of Kalyani. Many inscriptions, ranging between 10th and 12th centuries, indicate that Jainism was prominent in this region.
Supporters of art and literature, the Kalyani Chalukyas built Jain temples at places like Lakkundi, Shravanbelagola, Lakshmeshwar.
Numerous grants were given by royalty and common people to Jain establishments.

list.title: Solanki Rulers (Chaulukyas of Gujarat) 10th - 12th cent CE

bullet_points.description: The most glorious period of Jainism in western India was under the state support of Solankis, who ruled Gujarat and Rajasthan.
Also known as Chaulukyas of Gujarat, they encouraged art, architecture and literature establishing a firm stronghold, particularly of Shvetamabara Jain tradition, which sustains even today.
Intellectual and artistic activities contributed to some best known literary works and examples of fine architecture.
King Bhimadeva, who in spite his Shaivite leanings supported his minister Vimala to build the famous Vimala vasahi temple of Mt Abu.
Jain acharya _Hemachandra_ is associated with two of the powerful rulers of Solanki dynasty (c. 1050 CE – 1150 CE, Western India), Siddharaja Jaisimha and his successor, Kumarapala.
The famous disputation between great Shvetambara logician Vadideva-suri and a well-known Digambara scholar Kumudchandra took place at the court of Solanki king Siddharaja Jayasimha in 1124 CE.

Solanki King Kumarapala, originally a Shaivite, later embraced Jainism and elevated it to the status of State religion. He built important Jain temples at Palitana, Girnar,Taranga, Abu and Khambat, which are renowned pilgrim centres.

Acharya Abhaydev was known as _Nyayavanasimh and TarkaPanchanana_ for his outstanding work in _Nyaya_. He wrote several books, including commentaries on nine Shvetambara agamas. He also wrote _Tattvabodhini-tika_ on Acharya Siddhasena Divakara’s _Sammatitarka_.
Acharya Jinadatta Suri is the most celebrated Acharya of the sub-sect **Kharataragachchha of the** Shvetambar tradition.

His social, religious and literary activities earned him the title of ‘_Yuga-pradhana_'. Thousands joined the Jain community under his influence. His activities were spread over a large area covering present day Rajasthan, Gujarat, Maharashtra and Sindh. He was a great scholar of Sanskrit, Prakrit, and Apabhramsha.
%%Jinadatta Suri’s%% services to the community earned him great respect,  and the place of his death at Ajmer, was named the $$‘Dadavadi’$$.
As a tribute to his work, his followers established _dadavadis_ or _dadabaras_ throughout India. Leading ascetics of this sub-sect are known as _dada gurus_.

Various branches of this dynasty ruled parts of Rajputana and Central India between 10th and 12th centuries. Inscriptions indicate that at least two branches - Kacchapaghatas of Gwalior and Dubkund (Madhya Pradesh) promoted Jainism.
A scholar par excellence, Hemachandra was associated with powerful Solanki rulers, Siddharaja Jaisimha and Kumarpala. He wrote texts on yoga, grammar, poetry, logic and philosophy.
At the insistence of King Jayasimha, he composed the seminal text on grammar  _Siddha-Hema Shabdanushasana_ in the capital city of Anhilwad Patan, Patan district, northern Gujarat.
Hemachandra also composed _Kumarapalacharita_, a long poem in Prakrit and Sanskrit describing the glorious regime of the Solanki kings.
King Kumarapala, originally a Shaiva, ordered rebuilding of Somnath at Prabhas Patan and invited Hemachandra to visit the temple.
Hemachandra readily bowed down to Shiva at the temple, illustrating his approach to _anekantavada._
He said:

sub_bullet_points.description:
_Bhava Bijankaura-janana Ragadyam Kshayamupagata Yasya, Brahma va Vishnu va Haro Jino va Namastasmai._
I bow down to him who has destroyed the passions like attachment and malice which are the cause of the cycle of birth and death; whether he is Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva or Jina.

bullet_points.description: Hemachandra Suri was conferred the title of Kalikalasarvajna-The Knowledgeable One.

list.title: Shilahar Dynasty of Kolhapur (10th - 13th c. CE Deccan)

bullet_points.description: The Shilahara Dynasty that ruled over Kolhapur, Sangli, Satara regions of Maharashtra and parts of Belgavi district of Karnataka, mainly supported the Digambar Jain tradition.
Shilahara Kings, like Ballala and Gandaraditya, and some of their ministers, gave donations and grants to build Jain temples.
Inscription in the Parsvnath Temple, Kolhapur indicates states that a Jain basadi(temple) was created by Mahasamanta Nimbadevaras, minister of Shilahara king Gandaraditya.

central_timeline_details_lists.title: Story of Sala slaying the Tiger

list.title: Yadava Rulers 12th to 14th cent CE (1185 - 1313 CE) Deccan, Central India

bullet_points.description: The Yadav dynasty, at its peak ruled a territory including present-day Maharashtra, northern Karnataka and parts of Madhya Pradesh, from its capital at Devagiri (present-day Daulatabad in Maharashtra).
Inscriptions indicate grants of lands were made for building Jain temples during Yadava rule.
An inscription at the Jain temple near Anjaneri village indicates that a grant was made by Yadava king Seunadeva for the Chandraprabha Jain temple at Anjaneri in Saka Year 1063 (1141 CE).

Ashadharar was not an ascetic, but was very conversant with the intricacies of religious conduct, especially of the laity. He was a poet and scholar, associated with Mulasangha, a subsect of the Digambar Jain tradition.
In his famous work, Dharmamrita he has discussed the ideal code of conduct for householders - _Shravakachara_.
Jagadu Shah was a pious Jain and a prosperous merchant who renovated and built many Jain and few Hindu temples.
He organised and led pilgrimages of Jain community to places such as Shatrunjaya and Girnar.
During a severe famine, he helped people by providing grains from his own granaries.
Pethashaha was a Jain minister of Mandavgadh, Madhya Pradesh. He was devoted to Jainism and built 84 Jain temples across India.

Jain minister Thakkar Pheru held a prestigious position at the royal court of Alauddin Khalji. He was responsible for the royal mint and security of precious stones. Thakkar Pheru also served in this position under Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq. He wrote several books for his son Hemapal - Dravyaparīkṣa, Ratnaparikṣa (Pkt. Rayaṇaparikkhā), Vastusara.

Jinaprabha Suri was an esteemed Jain poet and grammarian. He composed _Vividha Tirtha Kalpa_, a compilation of Jain Tirthas in India. This is the only book that covers the history of pilgrimage sites upto 14th century CE, outlining the importance of pilgrim towns in Indian religious traditions.
He was the disciple of of Acharya Jinasimha of Laghu-khratara-gachchha. According to his text ‘_Vividhatirthakalpa_’ he met the sultan, Muhammad bin Tughlaq and visited his court several times.

According to Jain sources, Sultan Muhammad Tughlaq once invited acharya Jinaprabha Suri to the royal palace, treated him with respect and offered to give him wealth, land, horses, elephants, etc,  all of which the ascetic refused. The Sultan praised him for his austerity and issued a _farman_ for the construction of a new rest-house for ascetics.

central_timeline_details_lists.title: Destruction of Gwalior images by Babur​

bullet_points.description: Lonkashah belonged to the Shvetambara tradition, and founded the Lonkagaccha sect. He emphasised the core principle of non-possession, and stressed the importance of a travelling lifestyle for ascetics. He reformed Jain society by moving away from ritualism and image worship.

list.title: Taranapantha 16th cen CE
list.sub_title: TARANAPANTHA (TARAN SVAMI PANTH, TARAN SAMAJ, SAMAIYAPANTHA OR TARANAPANTHI)​

bullet_points.description: A Digambara sectarian tradition that follows the teachings of Tarana svami. Named after its founder, the sub-sect Taranapantha is also called Samaiyapantha as they worship Samaya - the sacred books. They lay more importance on spiritual values and thus there is complete absence of religious rituals. The three main traits of Taranapanthis are: rejection of idol-worship, ban on caste distinctions and absence of outward religious practices.​ They do not worship idols but only their own sacred books. Malharagarh, near Gwalior where Tarana Svami died is the main pilgrimage place for Taranapanthis.

The Mughal kings, particularly Akbar and Jahangir, respected the Jain religious tradition for the peaceful nature, practice of asceticism and intellectual qualities. Jain merchants were very influential and favoured by Mughal kings because of their financial acumen and accomplishments.
Hiravijaya Suri was a prominent Acharya of _Tapagachchha_, a sub-sect of the Shvetambar Jain tradition.
Acharya Hiravijaya Suri was invited by Emperor Akbar to his court.

Akbar was so impressed and influenced by the Acharya’s  non-violent religion, that Akbar issued decrees – _Amari Ghoshna_ – prohibiting animal slaughter during  Jain festivals _Paryushana_ and _Mahavir Jayanti_. He exempted Jain Tirtha places, like Palitana, from paying Jizia tax.

According to the historical account _Ain-i-Alebari,_ written by Abdul Fazal, Emperor Akbar bestowed upon him the **title of ‘Jagat-guru’ **as among the twenty-one most learned persons in the Mughal Empire .
After he led a large pilgrimage to Shatrunjaya in 1593 - 1594, the place underwent a revival in the following decades.

list.title: Pandit Banarasidasa, 16th cent CE, Jaunpur, Uttar Pradesh

bullet_points.description: Pandit Banarsidas was the first Indian author who wrote an autobiography - titled _Ardhakathanaka_ (The Half Story), composed in Braj Bhasha, an early dialect of Hindi.
This is the first  autobiography written in any Indian language.
Pandit Banarsidas was one of the leading proponents of the Adhyatma movement, which eventually led to the rise of Terapanth sect of the Digambar Jains.

‘Followers of the Twenty-Fold Path’ or ‘Universal (_vishva_) Path’ are one of the two main Digambara sectarian traditions in north India. In this tradition, Bhattarakas are the leaders of the religious institution known as ‘matha’.
This tradition accepts image worship.

This division of the Digambara Jain community took place in the mid-17th century with the Adhyatma movement and the subsequent establishment of a separate sectarian tradition known as Terapanth. When the name Terapanth came into use, Bhattarakas in north India started to refer to their tradition as the Bisapanth.
Followers of the  ‘Path of Thirteen (_teraha_)’ or ‘your (_tera_) path’.

Terapanthis rejected temple rituals that they believed were non-Jain in origin. Although they continued worshipping the images of Tirthankara, they rejected image worship of guardian deities, such as yaksha/yakshis.

The meaning of tera either denotes the path (pantha) of thirteen (13/teraha) or your (tera) path. 13 has been associated with 13 laymen from Adhyatma movement who build separate temples, or 13 principles of disagreement with the Bhattaraks of the Digambar Bisapanthi tradition.

Upadhyaya Yashovijay, a great intellectual was known as the ‘nyaya - visharada’ (expert in logic). He was a prolific author who wrote a number of books in four Indian languages (Sanskrit, Prakrit, Gujarati, Rajasthani), on a variety of aspects of Jain thought, including philosophy and spiritualism.

list.title: Acharya Bhikshu or Bhikhanji (Shvetambara) 18th – 19th cen. CE

bullet_points.description: Acharya Bhikshu or Bhikhanji was founder of the Shvetambar Terapanthi (तेरापंथी) sect. He introduced reforms in the conduct of the ascetics.
He originally belonged to the Shvetambar Sthanakavasi tradition.
Shvetambar Terapanth, founded by Acharya Bhikshu in 1760 CE, is one of the traditions that does not accept image worship.
The name ‘Terapanth’ is interpreted in three ways:

sub_bullet_points.description: Path of thirteen (13/ teraha) signifying the 13 monks who were the first followers of Acharya. Bhikshu, or
The 13-fold path of Mahavira, including the five ascetic vows (Mahavratas), the five limiting vows (samitis) and the three restrains (guptis).

bullet_points.description: Pandita Todarmala was an eminent writer and scholar of Jainism from Jaipur. He revived an interest in traditional Jain learning and wrote twelve books that include five original works and seven commentaries.
He wrote Hindi commentaries on important Digambara philosophical works viz., _Atmanushasana of Acharya Gunabhadra,_ and _Gommatasar, Labdhisara, Kshapakasar_ and _Trilokasar of Acharya Nemichandra._
About ten to twelve copyists were employed by him in different parts of the country, to make hand written copies of important Digambara texts.
In 1770, he established a set of rituals for his followers, and founded the sect that came to be known as _Gumanapantha_.
